title: Tasmanian mum's crusade to fight suicide in honour of lost son
text:
Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467 Beyond Blue on 1300 22 46 36 Headspace on 1800 650 890 
As well as dealing with her own grief over the loss of Albert, Ms Cuthbertson found herself helping her son's stunned friends. 
"There was really nowhere for them to go," she said. 
The tragedy and its wider effect drove Ms Cuthbertson to seek the help of Lifeline Tasmania to attempt to establish a safe-house for young people at risk. 
The concept of Albie House, named in honour of Albert, is loosely based on a United Kingdom model and is proposed as a place where "youth can access support and guidance 24/7 in a nurturing, non-clinical secure environment". 
The facility would offer "hope to youth at risk of suicide and those living with its effects", with a qualified mental health worker and support staff available at the 24-hour facility. Photo: Albert Cuthbertson died aged 16 in 2010. (Supplied: Amanda Cuthbertson) 
Three-quarters of all suicide deaths in Australia are male. 
As part of her mission to get Albie House realised, Ms Cuthbertson recently spoke to students at a Hobart boys school. 
"[Albert] was in Grade 10 like you guys," she told the assembled students. 
"There was a need for people who were great mates [with Albert] and had nowhere to turn." 
Student Oscar Chao said suicide among young men was "quite a large issue that needs to be dealt with". 
"I think that Albie House is a very important tool that can be used to solve this problem in our community." 
Fellow student Henry Chambers, 16, said he had been personally affected by the suicide of a friend. 
"It was a ripple effect ... it affected everyone around him," he said. 
Students at the boys' school can vote for a charity for to support. The last three years they have chosen Albie House. The agonising search for a reason why 
For a long time, Ms Cuthbertson looked for clues but never found an answer. 
While the initial grief has passed, she said some days were better than others. 
"It's something that is the first thing that's on your mind when you wake up and the last thing of a night," she said. 
Ms Cuthbertson said a crucial part of working through what happened was talking with others who had similarly suffered at a support group. Photo: The Morgans are yet to make sense of the suicide of their son Matthew (right). (ABC News) 
She met Ruth and Robert Morgan at a suicide support group after their son Matthew took his own life on his 30th birthday. 
"He was in Los Angeles, he was a commercial airline pilot ... he was living the life of his dreams, the thing that he had always wanted to do," Ms Morgan said. 
Like Ms Cuthbertson, the Morgan family has never discovered why their son made that choice, something they had agonised over. 
Ms Morgan said it took "years to stop for your own sanity just trying to work out why". 
"I think it's just something that we will never know," she said. 
The Morgan family said the support group was invaluable, but had since lost its funding. 
"Most of us who were in the support group over a number of years still meet, not as often as we once did, but we maintain the contact," Ms Morgan said. Kids 'don't want to pick up a phone' 
Lifeline Tasmania agreed that outside of acute emergency settings there was a lack of services for those affected by suicide. Photo: Amanda Cuthbertson said face-to-face interaction with young people was key. (ABC News) 
"At the moment there is a gap between people being discharged from emergency and actually having a safe place to go to," Lifeline Tasmania's Debbie Evans said. 
"Often when people are discharged they are going home on their own and ultimately are not connected to family or community, so are at risk." 
The Tasmanian Government has launched a suicide prevention strategy with five priority areas identified, including a better coordinated health response system. 
While that was welcomed by the Albie House group, Ms Cuthbertson said a non-medical residential facility was needed. Photo: Students at this Hobart school have voted for Albie House as their charity of choice. (ABC News) 
"When we were talking to a lot of youth at a forum they identified they didn't want to pick up the phone and talk to someone, they needed to feel that connection with someone face-to-face," she said. 
Albie House is not planned to be a drop-in centre, but a facility where young people up to the age of 25 can be referred to by a GP, their school, or community group. 
"It is a service that's never been operated or done before in Australia, it's the first of its kind, that's why it's taken a lot of time in planning and working how to get it up and running," she said. 
So far, Albie House has raised more than $100,000 as well as in-kind support, including the offer of a premises in central Hobart. Next month the first phase of the partnership with Lifeline is set to begin.
